key_points: President Donald Trump will not attend President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, breaking a tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.
Trump will be the first outgoing president since Andrew Johnson in 1869 to skip his successor's inauguration.
Other presidents who have missed their successors' inaugurations include John Adams in 1801 and John Quincy Adams in 1829.
Presidential historian Kate Andersen Brower emphasized the importance of attending the inauguration for the peaceful transfer of power and respect.
Trump's refusal to attend comes after weeks of making false claims of voter fraud in an attempt to overturn the election results.
President-elect Joe Biden expressed no issue with Trump's decision and welcomed Vice President Mike Pence's attendance.
The article recounts historical instances of outgoing presidents not attending their successors' inaugurations, including Johnson's feud with Grant and the Adams situations.
Some presidents missed their successors' inaugurations due to other reasons, such as poor health or under different circumstances.
Former Presidents George H.W. Bush and Jimmy Carter, despite taking their losses personally, attended their successors' inaugurations, respecting tradition.
The article highlights Trump's reluctance to partake in Washington traditions and his history of holding grudits.
